text: Hey, this is Henry. I am here to talk about how MinuteEarth videos get made.
We're a truly internet-based production company.  We have at times spanned eight times zones,

so we communicate using tools like
Slack, Dropbox and Google Hangouts and

a bunch of other things for file sharing
and working together in collaborating on

creative projects across the world.
MinuteEarth videos begin as an idea or pitch from

somebody - one of our writers - who's
excited about something and want to

share it and they tell the rest of us
about it and we ask questions and get

normally also excited about it they go
off and learn more about it and do

research and come back with a draft. In
the research process writers will either

read books or scientific papers to learn
about material themselves or they'll talk
to researchers to find out what's the newest thing in the field or try to

get a better sense of understanding of
the subject. It's a very iterative process
of revisions, and drafts, and revisions and drafts that sometimes involves conversations
between editor and writer, or feedback from the entire team. And then at the end we do a little bit of tiding up of the writing

and he goes off the narrator and they
narrate the video. Then we send the audio to Ever

who does the audio editing and he'll cut the narration down
from a bunch of takes,
often with mistakes, into something that sounds good and is part of the video. And we must not
forget that we also add music to the video as well. Then we go into storyboarding where the illustrator for the video

will do kind of rough sketches for what
is going to happen in each scene of the video.

We will have several iterations of video
storyboards, where we're trying to get feedback
from everyone, and the writer particularly, but also everyone on the team

as to how we can best visually convey the
material we're talking about.
Only when we have zeroed in where we are going with the storyboard, do we then have the illustrator

do the final fancy looking drawings. We
invariably have multiple at that stage

as well but because the final drawings
take more time we try to get as close to

the ideal video as possible in the
storyboards stage so you don't have to

spend as much time doing the
illustrations of changing illustrations

that we already spent a lot of time doing. Finally once it is done we
will post it online on places like Vessel and
YouTube so that you can watch it, which is, I assume, where you're watching this video.

This might sound like a long and convoluted process but
it's made extra complicated by the fact

that we're actually doing this in
parallel for up to 8 videos at a time
